keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a pardoned Capitol rioter, has been arrested for making a credible death threat against House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan allegedly planned to kill Jeffries during a speech at the Economic Club of New York and expressed intent to eliminate him in text messages.
Trump pardoned Moynihan in 2021, calling him a 'hostage' whose life was 'destroyed,' despite his involvement in a violent act that disrupted democratic processes.

Moynihan was among the first rioters to breach police barricades during the January 6 Capitol riot and was seen flipping through a notebook and taking photos, suggesting possible intent to gather information.
The incident highlights ongoing concerns about political violence and the potential dangers posed by individuals pardoned for their actions in a Capitol riot.
Hakeem Jeffries, a top Democrat and potential future Speaker, expressed gratitude for law enforcement actions but criticized the pardoning of violent individuals who pose credible threats.
This case reflects a broader pattern of political violence in the U.S. this year, including the killing of a Minnesota lawmaker and a shooting of activist Charlie Kirk in September 2024.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher Moynihan, a 34-year-old man pardoned by former President Donald Trump for his role in the January 6, 2021 Capitol riot, has been arrested and charged with making a credible threat to kill House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Moynihan allegedly planned to target Jeffries during a speech at the Economic Club of New York, expressing in text messages that Jeffries 'must be eliminated' and that he 'will kill him for the future.' This incident comes amid a broader wave of political violence in the U.S., including the killing of a Minnesota lawmaker and the fatal shooting of activist Charlie Kirk. Moynihan, who was sentenced to 21 months in prison for breaching Capitol barricades and taking photos of lawmakers, is being held in Poughkeepsie and has pleaded not guilty. The case raises serious questions about the implications of pardoning individuals involved in violent acts against democratic institutions and the ongoing threat to public safety from political extremism.
title: Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested for allegedly threatening to kill Hakeem Jeffries
